user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_tell:
```c
lfs_soff_t lfs_dir_tell(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_tell(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)dir);

    lfs_soff_t res = lfs_dir_tell_(lfs, dir);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_tell -> %"PRId32, res);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_tell:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static lfs_soff_t lfs_dir_tell_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    (void)lfs;
    return dir->pos;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I reviewed all occurrences of the function parameters lfs and dir in the provided code. There are no assignments to the parameter variables (no statements like lfs = ... or dir = ...), and no operations that reassign these pointers. Specific notes:
- lfs_dir_tell: parameters are only used to access members (lfs->cfg) and passed to LFS_TRACE and lfs_dir_tell_ — passing a pointer or using its members does not modify the pointer itself.
- LFS_LOCK and LFS_UNLOCK macros expand to expressions that only reference cfg but do not modify the lfs pointer or the pointed-to object.
- LFS_TRACE is empty and the casts (void*)lfs, (void*)dir do not modify the pointers.
- lfs_dir_tell_: contains (void)lfs; (unused-parameter suppression) and returns dir->pos (reads the object pointed to). Reading or modifying the pointee is permitted by Rule 17.8; here only a read occurs.
Therefore, there are no code fragments that modify function parameter variables and no fragments needing further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
